meanings.definition: To make something conform to a standard.
meanings.sent1: We need to standardise the process to ensure everyone follows the same steps.
meanings.sent2: It is important to standardise the measurements so that they are consistent.
meanings.sent3: Trying to standardise the chaos of my room is like herding cats.
meanings.sent4: She tried to standardise her study routine, but it felt like fitting a square peg in a round hole.
meanings.sent5: The teacher used a color-coding system to standardise the organization of the classroom.

meanings.definition: To establish a standard for something.
meanings.sent1: Let's standardise the criteria for evaluating the projects.
meanings.sent2: The company aims to standardise the quality of their products across all branches.
meanings.sent3: Deciding to standardise the pizza toppings caused quite a stir among the employees.
meanings.sent4: She wanted to standardise the rules of the game, making it fair for everyone.
meanings.sent5: The chef worked hard to standardise the recipes to maintain consistency in taste.

meanings.definition: To bring something into conformity with a standard.
meanings.sent1: We must standardise our procedures to meet industry regulations.
meanings.sent2: The team worked together to standardise the format of the report.
meanings.sent3: His attempt to standardise his wardrobe to only black clothes was met with mixed reactions.
meanings.sent4: She tried to standardise her handwriting to make it neater and more legible.
meanings.sent5: The goal is to standardise the safety protocols to prevent accidents in the workplace.
